title: The UMC Utrecht NE group: An introduction
text:
Welcome to the blog of the nephroepidemiology group at the UMC Utrecht! Here, we will share interesting publications (both from our own group and from other researchers), give updates on conferences we attended, and share posts aimed at laymen (written in understandable Dutch).
To kick things off, today, we had our first get together. Although the nephroepidemiology group has existed for a longer time, this was given shape in an informal manner. Today marks the first occurrence of our biweekly recurring meeting. These meetings will serve not only as a short moment to connect with each other, but also to discuss currently ongoing projects, discuss articles, give talks, host external speakers, etc.
…
To finish off, I’ll append an R trick to each post (until I run out of tricks)

This post’s R-trick: multicursor
Did you know you can activate a multicursor in R? This allows you to write the same code on multiple lines simultaneously. Great for if you are writing code in bulk! To activate it, simply hold the Alt/Option key and drag the cursor along the lines that you want the cursor to apply to. On some operating systems, you may need to press the Alt/Option key one more time to activate the cursor. Happy bulk-writing!
An example from Stackoverflow 




 Back to top

title: NE Utrecht
text:
Hi! Welcome to the homepage of the nephroepidemiology research group of the University Medical Center (UMC) Utrecht.

Our team is diverse in its background and specialties, but all members share the same mission: improving clinical care and outcomes for individuals with chronic kidney disease, those on dialysis, and kidney transplant recipients, using epidemiological methods and big data.
To this end, we use advanced epidemiological and data scientific methods, applied to a wide range of large and granular data sources, including randomised controlled trials, cohort studies, electronic health records, and registries.
We are located at the UMC Utrecht. Our team is embedded in the Department of Nephrology and Hypertension and in Utrecht Patient Oriented Database (UPOD) of the Central Diagnostics Laboratory.





UMC Utrecht


This collaboration gives us access both to direct clinical involvement and to the high-quality research infrastructure of UPOD.
Want to know more? Check out our currently running projects and previous output.



 Back to top

title: Team members
text:
We are a diverse group of researchers, who all bring our own specialties and skills that complement the team.




Robin W. M. Vernooij
ORCID: 0000-0001-5734-4566
Robin is an assistant professor at the UMC Utrecht, and spearheads this research group. He received his PhD on improving guideline methodology and reporting from the Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona (Spain). Having previously worked at Cochrane and the Dutch Cancer Registry, and currently working as epidemiologist at the Dutch Kidney Registry, Robin’s academic work is strengthened by ample experience in registry research and evidence synthesis.






Roemer J. Janse
ORCID: 0000-0003-0059-872X
Roemer is a clinical epidemiologist, working on the interplay of nephrology, immunology, and virology in kidney transplantation recipients. He completed his BSc in Medicine and afterwards finished his PhD on causal inference and prediction modelling in people with CKD, at the Leiden University Medical Center (The Netherlands) and Karolinska Institutet (Sweden). Besides his clinical projects, he provides epidemiological and programming support.






Cindy P. Porras
ORCID: 0000-0001-7692-9164
Cindy is a medical doctor and clinical epidemiologist, applying her knowledge to the cardiorenal axis. She performed multiple studies on sex differences in peripheral arterial disease and is currently investigating heart failure and its interplay with kidney disease. Her thesis also has a methodological component, with a specific focus on prediction modelling.






Julia M.T. Colombijn
ORCID: 0000-0002-9022-5937
Julia is a PhD student currently finishing her medical studies. Her PhD research focuses on polypharmacy in individuals with chronic kidney disease. Besides elucidating the extent of polypharmacy in this population, she has also studied the lack of evidence for multiple common cardiorenal protective drugs and has further investigated their use in this population.






Denise M.J. Veltkamp
ORCID: 0000-0001-9914-7827
Denise is a medical doctor whose research focuses on long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury. To get a broad overview, she has performed multiple meta-analyses and clustering studies, and worked on developing prediction models to get personalised insights in these long-term outcomes. Additionally, she has previously done research on the patient perspective in kidney transplantation.






Sanne Roos
ORCID: 0009-0004-7225-8542
Sanne is a medical doctor, doing her PhD on haemodiafiltration. Not only is she investigating the possible mechanisms through which haemodiafiltraiton improves survival; she is also working to assess the effect of haemodiafiltration in a real-world population and obtain individualised estimates of its effect over haemodialysis.






Ellis Oortwijn
ORCID: 0009-0004-5917-8716
Ellis is a PhD student with a background in cardiovascular health and disease. Bringing with her experience in both fundamental and clinical research, she now focuses on the utilisation, safety, and effectiveness of cardiovascular risk management in individuals with chronic kidney disease.





 Back to top

title: NE Utrecht
text:
For inquiries about individual papers, please contact the corresponding author of the respective paper.
Interested in collaborating? Please contact Robin Vernooij (rvernoo2@umutrecht.nl).
This website is maintained by Roemer Janse. Any notes on content can be communicated to rjanse5@umcutrecht.nl.




 Back to top

title: Currently ongoing projects
text: We have a number of overarching research lines, within which we perform most of our research. Besides these research lines, we also collaborate with other researchers on the broader spectrum of cardio-kidney-metabolic epidemiological research and methodological development and innovation.

title: Currently ongoing projects
section: Long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury
text:
Long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury
This research line focusses on the long-term outcomes after kidney injury, both through a predicitve lens and a relational lens.

People working on this

DeniseRobinRoemer






In this line of research, Denise is in the lead. She has written multiple papers on the topic and more analyses are underway. She is responsible for coming up with new avenues within the project, writing papers and performing analyses.








Robin is the principal investigator in this project. He ensures the project is heading in the best direction it can, seeks funding to continue work, and contributes new research ideas. In this role, he supervises Denise.








In this project, Roemer provides methodological and programming support where needed, both sollicited and unsollicited.

title: Currently ongoing projects
section: Kidney Tx through the lens of nephrology, immunology, and virology

title: De nier-data onderzoeksgroep van het UMC Utrecht
text:
Welkom op de blog van de nier-data onderzoeksgroep van het UMC Utrecht. Leuk dat u meeleest. Hier, op onze website, vindt u informatie over ons team en de projecten waar we mee bezig zijn. We begrijpen dat die informatie niet altijd makkelijk te lezen is, doordat het Engels is en gericht is op andere onderzoekers. Daarom hebben we ook deze blog. Op deze blog delen wij interessante informatie voor een breder publiek in begrijpbaar Nederlands, zoals dit bericht. Dit soort berichten staan onder het kopje ‘In begrijpbare taal’.



 Terug naar boven
